The  proposed  $300  million  rupiah-equivalent  program  will  be  sourced 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources and then converted to rupiah by 
entering  into  cross-currency  swaps.  ADB  will  then  provide  10-year

banks  will  carry  interest  rates  based  on  the  cost  of  funds,  as  well  as 
margins as determined by ADB’s investment committee. The committee 
will also determine up-front and commitment fees in respect of the loans 
to the participating banks.  
 
The  Housing  Finance  Program  will  also  consist  of  TA  for  each 
participating  bank.  The  TA  will  be  provided  under  the  existing  TA  for

(TA  7469).  The  objective  of  this  TA  is  to  help  banks  strengthen 
mortgage lending practices, thereby improving institutional capacity and 
enabling banks to reach lower-income customers. 
 
Comprehensive due diligence conducted by ADB to gauge the viability

availability  of  competitively  priced  local  currency  funding,  and  (iv)  the 
credit risk of participating banks, including potential weakening of asset 
quality as banks move down market to lower-income borrowers.

TA  will  help  participating  banks  better  develop  other  new 
products and market this new fixed-rate product.

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Economic and Sector Background1 

General.  Compared  to  global  and  regional  standards,  Indonesia’s  financial  sector  is 
2.

gross domestic product (GDP), which is considerably less than the size of the financial sectors 
in large Asian economies such as India, where the equivalent figure is 300%, and the People’s 
Republic of China, where the figure is 500%.2 With a limited number of pension funds, insurance 
companies,  and  nonbanking  institutions,  Indonesia’s  financial  sector  is  characterized  by  the 
dominance of the banking industry, which controls about 80% of assets in the financial system 
(footnote  2).  Despite  a  high  number  of  commercial  banks  operating  in  this  sector,  10  banks 
control about 64% of total assets in the system3, and four large state-owned commercial banks 
own about 36% of the assets in the banking industry.4  
 
3. 
Limited services and reach. Although Indonesia is well served in terms of number of 
banks (some of which have been operating for decades), the sector is still shallow, with limited 
reach  and  services.  For  instance,  mortgage  lending,  a  fundamental  activity  of  commercial 
banking sector in many countries, is very underdeveloped. At the end of June 2010, mortgage 
loans  represented  only  about  8%  of  aggregate  commercial  bank  loan  portfolios  (footnote  3). 
Compared  with  developed  countries  such  as  Canada,  where  mortgage  loans  comprise  about 
40%  of  banks'  total  lending  portfolios,  this  is  quite  low.5  In  the  aftermath  of  the  1997  Asian

Recent  performance.  The  direct  impact  on  the  Indonesian  banking  sector  from  the 
global financial crisis was minimized due to limited exposure to global financial assets, stricter 
lending  rules  imposed  by  Bank  Indonesia,  and  efforts  by  the  banks  to  bolster  their  respective

levels of growth in 2009 and 2010 in aggregate loans and deposits, albeit at slower rates. Fitch 
Ratings expects the financial performance of Indonesian banks to improve throughout 2010 due 
to the more favorable macroeconomic outlook and lower credit costs as loan quality continues 
to improve (Appendix 3 provides detailed information on the banking industry). 
 
5. 
Housing  finance  subsector  overview.  A  well-developed  housing  finance  market  is 
critical  for  both  the  financial  (banks,  nonbank  financial  institutions,  and  bond  markets)  and 
housing  sectors.10  In  the  case  of  Asia,  the  region's  housing  finance  markets  are  quite 
underdeveloped. As such, the urgent housing needs of many of the Asian Development Bank’s 
(ADB’s)  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  are  unmet.  The  mortgage  debt-to-GDP  ratio,  a 
measure of the depth of a country's housing finance market, is well below 15% in a number of 
countries  (Figure  1).  This  statistic  is  particularly  striking  when  compared  to  other  emerging 
market  regions.  For  example,  the  average  mortgage  debt-to-GDP  ratio  in  South  Asia  is  2.9%, 
and  in  East  Asia  and  the  Pacific  it  is  only  1.5%.  This compares  with  a  mortgage  debt-to-GDP 
ratio of 7% in Latin America and the Caribbean and 11% in sub-Saharan Africa.11 Indonesia's 
mortgage market, strikingly, is one of the least developed in Asia at approximately 2% of GDP.

7. 
Mortgage  lending  practices  are  generally  conservative.    As  a  result,  mortgage  loans  in 
the nonsubsidized sector have performed relatively well, with low levels of nonperforming loans 
(NPLs). Mortgage loans are offered on an 8-, 10-, 15-, or 20-year basis; however, the average 
loan tenor is 7–8 years. The actual loan tenor indicates that, while banks may advertise longer 
tenor  loans,  the  practice  is  to  provide  shorter-term  loans.  Down  payments  range  from  20%  to 
30% of the property cost, but can vary significantly depending upon the type of borrower. With 
respect to geographic concentration, about 50%–60% of banks’ mortgage portfolios are located 
in the greater Jakarta area. This is due primarily to high demand and developer activity in this 
area. Additionally, NPLs, as noted by banks, tend to be lower in the greater Jakarta area.  
 
While banks provide mortgages with a number of different features, the basic product in 
8. 
the  nonsubsidized  market  is  the  adjustable-rate  mortgage  (ARM).  ARMs  are  not  capped  and 
rates  are  adjusted  at  the  discretion  of  the  lender  and  not  linked  to  a  cost  of  funds  index.  In 
2004/2005, banks offered mortgage loans with a fixed-rate period of 1 year, which then reset to 
a  floating  rate  loan  for  the  remaining  tenor.  Today,  responding  to  the  demand  for  longer-term 
fixed-rate loans, banks offer mortgage loans with 1–3 year fixed-rate periods, which then reset 
to ARMs for the remainder of the life of the loan. In the Islamic banking market, banks do offer 
mortgage products that are similar to fixed-rate loans. However, Islamic banking in Indonesia is 
still quite new and represents about 2%–3% of banking assets. Thus, volumes of these types of 
mortgages are very low (footnote 2).14 It is important to note that the fixed-rate ARM products 
are  generally  not  matched  by  fixed-rate  funding  for  the  banks,  which  creates  a  risk  for  the 
banks.  With  respect  to  interest  rates,  there  has  been  a  decrease  from  a  high  of  16%–18%  in 
2005 to about 9%–12% currently. There is no risk-based pricing in the market, as interest rates 
are typically set according to product based on a margin and cost of funds.  
 
9. 
As  a  result  of  the  shallow  banking  sector  and  underdeveloped  housing  finance 
subsector,  mortgage  lending  is  quite  restrictive  and  is  targeted  to  a  bifurcated  borrower  base.  
Higher  income  clients  have  been  serviced  by  the  commercial  banks,  while  lower  income 
borrowers are assisted by BTN.  As a result, UN-HABITAT estimates that only the top 30% of 
people  in  Indonesia  have  access  to  mortgages  (footnote  13).    Thus,  there  is  a  large  group  of 
people who could afford mortgages, but who do not currently have access to them.

include  a  number  of  factors.  Down  payments  for  home  purchases  can  be  high  for  average 
income  borrowers.    In  emerging  markets  in  particular,  borrowers  have  difficulty  accumulating 
funds for down payments on homes. Indonesia also has some of the highest transaction costs 
related to home purchases in the region.16 Consumer information is also not easily obtainable or 
documented.  While  Bank  Indonesia  does  maintain  a  bad-debt  repository,  there  is  no  credit 
bureau with robust consumer data (the International Finance Corporation is currently providing 
technical assistance to develop a credit bureau). The appraisal industry is also underdeveloped, 
with  banks  typically  undertaking  in-house  appraisals,  and  there  is  no  single  data  source  for 
integrated  housing  information.  Land  registration  in  Indonesia  is  complex  and  somewhat 
confusing. Foreclosure, while possible, is costly and can be lengthy in certain instances.

been offered on a shorter-term basis to all but the wealthiest borrowers because 
banks have had access largely to short-term deposit bases. The capital markets

Deepening  and  broadening  of  the  Indonesian  finance  sector.  The  program

(i) 

 
Justification for the proposed ADB loan is based on the following considerations: 

Lack of access to long-term funds. The program will provide systemic support 
to the Indonesian financial sector at a critical point in its development. Access to 
formal  banking  services  has  been  restricted.  Moreover,  the  availability  of  long-
term  local  currency  funds,  particularly  at  fixed  rates,  is  constrained.  Such 
absence results in banks having maturity mismatch risk and a limited number of 
longer-term mortgage products. ADB will thus be providing critically needed long-
term funding for the growth of this market. 
 
Innovative intervention to develop the housing finance market. The Housing 
Finance  Program  will  play  a  pioneering  role  in  encouraging  the  provision  of 
mortgage loans to lower-income consumers in the Indonesian market through the 
introduction of long-term FRMs. To date, no such intervention has been designed 
for  this  market,  and  local  banks  have  only  been  able  to  offer  shorter-term  fixed 
rate components.  

Capacity  building  technical  assistance.  ADB’s  value  addition  in  terms  of  TA 
for  mortgage  lending  capacity  building  is  strong.  As  noted,  given  the  relative 
underdevelopment  of  the  housing market,  mortgage  lending  skills  and servicing 
practices  could  be  strengthened.  Tailored  TA  for  each  participating  bank,  as  is 
contemplated,  is  important  for  the  prudent  growth  of  the  mortgage  market  in 
Indonesia.

ECONOMIC OVERVIEW 

 
1. 
The  Indonesian  economy  was  resilient  throughout  the  global  financial  crisis  in  2008–
2009. The country's economy grew 4.5% in 2009, in sharp contrast to the 2.8% contraction in 
world gross domestic product (GDP). In 2010, GDP growth accelerated to 5.9% in the first half 
of the year, supported mostly by private consumption, which contributed to nearly half the total 
GDP  growth.  Fixed  capital  investment,  contributing  to  1.8%  of  GDP  growth  in  the  period,  was 
supported  by  the  appreciation  of  the  rupiah  against  the  dollar,  which  lowered  the  cost  of 
imported capital equipment and provided a lift in credit to the private sector. On the supply side, 
services contributed more than half (3.7%) of the total GDP growth in the first 6 months of the 
year. Industry expanded by 4.4%, with a moderate recovery in manufacturing. Other economic 
indicators  have  also  been  positive.  After  remaining  below  4%  for  about  a  year,  inflation 
accelerated to slightly over 6% in July and August 2010 due to temporary pressure from volatile 
food prices. The Jakarta Stock Exchange composite index of share prices climbed by 21.6% in 
the first 8 months of 2010, supported by solid economic performance, an appreciating exchange 
rate, and increased purchases from foreign investors. Indonesia’s economic outlook is expected 
to improve further and economic growth for 2010 is forecasted at 6%. 
 
2. 
The country’s fiscal performance in 2009 was also better than expected, with the budget 
deficit  recorded  at  1.6%  of  GDP.  The  year-end  tax  revenue  was  on  target,  while  on  the 
expenditure  side,  the  government  maintained  spending  within  budget.  The  2010  budget  was 
revised in May 2010, which widened the budget deficit target from 1.6% of GDP to 2.1% of GDP 
due  to  higher  international  oil  prices  than  originally  expected  and  additional  spending  for 
physical  infrastructure,  poverty  reduction,  education,  and  for  reconstruction  of  earthquake-
damaged infrastructure. However, only about 35% of the 2010 budget spending was disbursed 
in  the  first  half  of  2010.  Revenue,  on  the  other  hand,  was  supported  from  the  economic 
recovery,  higher  oil  prices  and  production,  and  policies  to  improve  the  performance  of  state-
owned enterprises. Therefore, the budget deficit for the year is expected to be lower, at 1.5% of 
GDP. On the financing side, between January and the end of August 2010 about 78.4% of the
